Comment: Now we like due process and the constitution? What about COVID? Where was the due process then? In California (Los Angeles specifically) they were able to suspend the constitution, citing emergency orders and safety. They were able to suspend the sixth amendment for anyone who had been arrested and charged of a crime. You could be sitting in jail indefinitely until the emergency mandate (which is based on a virus that had less than 1% fatality rate) until they deemed it "safe." Also, if you did finally go to trial, you didn't have the right to face your accuser due to the fact that it was deemed unsafe to be in the same room; again, going against the constitution.  Multiple people were arrested, simply for going outside (for example, the lone paddle border) and many businesses had to be shut down. Also, anyone who was suspected of having a gathering of multiple people in the residence could (and did) have their power cut out again leaving out any due process all while our governor was dining indoors at the French Laundry. Children were not allowed to go to school due to a virus that affected children even less than adults and as a result we have one of the most anxious generation of children with no social skills. We have multiple businesses, small businesses and restaurants shut down that no longer exist due to the fact that they enacted these emergency mandates. We also had people being fired from their jobs and the military due to refusing to take a medical treatment that was mandated on people which once again we found out wasn‚Äôt as effective as they initially said. People were fired from jobs over this. Where was ‚Äúdue process‚Äù then?
Author: zero708970
